org.openimaj.audio

Class SampleChunk

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.openimaj.audio.Audio
      • org.openimaj.audio.SampleChunk

  • public class SampleChunk
extends Audio
    Represents a chunk of an audio file and stores the raw audio data. The data is unnormalised - that is, it is stored in this class in its original format in the form of a byte array. This is for speed during audio playback. If you require normalised data (data as an integer array for example) use the method getSamplesAsByteBuffer() and use the ByteBuffer's methods asXXXBuffer (e.g. ByteBuffer#asShortBuffer) to get the samples in a normalised form.
    Author:
    David Dupplaw (dpd@ecs.soton.ac.uk)

      • getNumberOfSamples

        public int getNumberOfSamples()
        Returns the number of samples in this sample chunk. If there are 128 stereo samples, this method will return 256. That is, it does not normalise for the number of channels. However, it does normalise for the size of each sample. So if this is a 16-bit buffer of 256 bytes length, this method will return 128.
        Returns:
        the number of samples in this sample chunk.

      • getSamplesAsByteBuffer

        public ByteBuffer getSamplesAsByteBuffer()
        Returns a ByteBuffer that can be used to create views of the samples in the object. For example, to get short integers, you can get getSamplesAsByteBuffer().asShortBuffer()
        Returns:
        A ByteBuffer

      • getSampleBuffer

        public SampleBuffer getSampleBuffer()
        Returns an appropriate sample buffer for this sample chunk. If an appropriate sample buffer cannot be found, null will be returned. This will wrap the samples array from the underlying chunk, so you should only side-affect the samples if you're sure they will not be reused.
        Returns:
        An appropriate SampleBuffer

      • setStartTimecode

        public void setStartTimecode(AudioTimecode startTimecode)
        Set the timecode at the start of this audio chunk.
        Parameters:
        startTimecode - the timecode at the start of the chunk.

      • getStartTimecode

        public AudioTimecode getStartTimecode()
        Get the timecode at the start of this audio chunk.
        Returns:
        the timecode at the start of the chunk.

      • getSampleSlice

        public SampleChunk getSampleSlice(int start,
                                  int length)
        Return a slice of data from the sample array. The indices are based on the samples in the byte array, not the bytes themselves.

        The assumption is that samples are whole numbers of bytes. So, if the sample size was 16-bits, then passing in 2 for the start index would actually index the byte at index 4 in the underlying sample array. The order of the bytes is unchanged.

        Parameters:
        start - The start index of the sample.
        length - The length of the samples get.
        Returns:
        The sample slice as a new SampleChunk

      • prepend

        public SampleChunk prepend(SampleChunk sample)
        Prepends the given samples to the front of this sample chunk. It is expected that the given samples are in the same format as this sample chunk; if they are not an exception is thrown. Side-affects this sample chunk and will return a reference to this sample chunk.
        Parameters:
        sample - the samples to add
        Returns:
        This sample chunk with the bytes prepended

      • append

        public SampleChunk append(SampleChunk sample)
        Appends the given samples to the end of this sample chunk. It is expected that the given samples are in the same format as this sample chunk; if they are not an exception is thrown. Side-affects this sample chunk and will return a reference to this sample chunk.
        Parameters:
        sample - the samples to add
        Returns:
        This sample chunk with the bytes appended
